Expectation1: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation1: A transit authority superviO35r has just entered the cabin for an immediate and unannounced performance audit.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story: I sat in the operator’s seat, hands steady on the controls as the subway rumbled through the tunnel. The supervisor’s sudden entrance made my heart race—clipboard in hand, eyes sharp, ready to scrutinize every move. I knew the rules: no distractions, perfect timing, absolute focus. My job, my livelihood, depended on this audit. Yet, my phone vibrated in my pocket, a reminder of the sacred duty awaiting me above ground. Today was the holiest day of the year, the one service my congregation counted on me to lead. They expected my presence, my words, my guidance. I could almost hear the hymns, feel the weight of their hopes. But here, underground, the city demanded something else: precision, discipline, unwavering attention. My mind spun between the two worlds—one of steel and schedules, the other of faith and community. The supervisor’s pen hovered, ready to judge. My congregation waited, trusting I would not let them down. I gripped the controls tighter, torn by the impossible pull of both callings, knowing I could not be in two places at once.
